text: The next potential battle between the Trump administration and business leaders is near, and it’s on immigration.

headline: Jason Fried of Basecamp on the Importance of Writing Skills
text: This interview with Jason Fried, chief executive of Basecamp, a web-based project management tool, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: A Green Light for Art Criminals?
text: LONDON — The horrific Grenfell Tower fire, which claimed the lives of about 80 residents of an apartment block here in June, has had a number of unforeseen consequences.

headline: When Colleagues Won’t Stop Talking Politics
text: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: Willie Nelson, Roky Erickson, Eric Clapton: Twang, Psychedelia and Blues
text: With all eyes on a hurricane-torn Texas, its perpetually touring musicians carry a spirit of resilience. Willie Nelson, despite recent respiratory problems, has been barnstorming across America with his encompassing repertoire of Americana. This weekend he headlines the Outlaw Music Festival of roots-rock and country in amphitheaters: Friday, Sept. 8, at PNC Bank Arts Center in Holmdel, N.J., and Saturday at Jones Beach Theater in Wantagh, N.Y. The lineup includes his son’s band, Lukas Nelson and Promise of the Real, along with Sheryl Crow, the Avett Brothers and Margo Price. The paladin of Texas psychedelia, Roky Erickson — who led the 13th Floor Elevators in the 1960s and returned, after some difficult years personally, with garage-rock visions of aliens, demons and redemption — performs in Brooklyn on Wednesday and Thursday at Rough Trade and Jersey City on Friday at White Eagle Hall. Meanwhile, Eric Clapton is bringing Austin bluesmen as openers — and rivals — when he plays Madison Square Garden on Thursday and Friday, sharing the bill with the incendiary guitarist Gary Clark Jr. and with Jimmie Vaughan, a founder of the Fabulous Thunderbirds.

headline: What Do Harrison Ford and a Homicidal Clown Have in Common?
text: It only took a day for a sinister 31-year-old clown to outpace the combined powers of Vin Diesel and Dwayne Johnson, a.k.a The Rock.

headline: David Litt, an Obama Speechwriter Who Wants No Credit
text: Washington is filled with political operatives who inflate their importance and take credit, oftentimes where it might not be due.

headline: Amanda Seales of ‘Insecure’ Revisits Her Harlem Haunts
text: As Amanda Seales strode into Ginny’s Supper Club, the nightspot under the Red Rooster in Harlem on a recent Thursday, a young woman pulled her aside, saying, “You are fabulous, honey.” At the fan’s request, the two took a pout-perfect selfie.

headline: Teenagers in The Times: August 2017
text: After a summer break, we present the first edition of Teenagers in The Times of the new school year. On the first Friday of each month, you’ll find a roundup of the news and feature stories about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com.

headline: Michael Dell, Tech Billionaire, Pledges $36 Million in Harvey Relief
text: Michael Dell, the billionaire Texan who founded Dell Technologies, has pledged $36 million of his foundation’s money to help disaster relief efforts in the wake of Hurricane Harvey.

headline: California Today: Firefighters, at Less Than $2 an Hour
text: Good morning.

headline: Deporting Dreamers
text: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

headline: Harvey Updates: Fire and Smoke Again Engulf Chemical Plant Near Houston
text: Fire engulfed part of a chemical plant northeast of Houston on Friday evening, sending thick black smoke high into the sky, a statement from Arkema, the owner of the plant, confirmed. It was the same facility where, on Thursday, a chemical storage trailer exploded, setting off a fire. Flooding from Harvey, once a Category 4 hurricane that hit southeast Texas last week, had knocked out the refrigeration system needed to keep the chemicals stable.

headline: Capturing Action Just Off the Court at the U.S. Open
text: I am always attracted to the edges because they define shape and give context. And I always seek a spark of photographic magic on the edges of light and shadow. So when I was tasked to cover the opening days of the United States Open this year, I found myself looking to the margins of both the action and the light as the world’s premier players performed an exquisitely elegant dance of athleticism and grace with the assistance of an army of support: ball boys and ball girls, line judges and members of the security staff, working in view of a sea of awe-inspired fans, myself included. I worked the courtside edges, from Arthur Ashe Stadium to the practice courts, to incorporate some of those people into photographs that usually strive to be free of distractions, and I allowed myself the pleasure of finding beauty as the players tried to gain their own edge.

headline: Trump Again Lashes Out at Comey’s Handling of Clinton Investigation
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Friday lashed out anew at the F.B.I. director he fired in May, charging that James B. Comey had “exonerated” Hillary Clinton before fully completing the investigation into her use of a private email server.

headline: Switching Between Apple’s iOS and Google’s Android
text: Q. How hard is it to switch smartphone systems from Android to the new iPhone that is coming out this fall? Do I have to buy all new apps? And if I ever want to change back to Android, how much of a hassle is it?

headline: Farhad’s and Nick’s Week in Review: Uber’s New Boss and Amazon’s New Supermarket
text: Each Friday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Mike is out this week so Nick Wingfield, a Times technology reporter based in Seattle, filled in.

headline: A 16-Room Penthouse at the Pierre Sells for $44 Million
text: One of the city’s most expensive apartment listings — a rambling triplex perched atop the venerable Pierre Hotel overlooking Central Park — has finally sold after more than four years on and off the market.

headline: Football Favoritism at F.S.U.: The Price One Teacher Paid
text: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — As the Florida State University football team was marching to a national title in the fall of 2013, the school was investigating allegations of academic favoritism involving a half-dozen of its leading players, including one who scored the winning touchdown in the championship game.

headline: The Illustrated Interview: Alex Trebek
text: The “Jeopardy!” host sketched his answers at his desk with both a regular and an Extra Fine Point Sharpie while sipping a glass of chardonnay.

headline: Nafta Negotiations: What’s at Stake in the Second Round
text: Trade negotiators from Canada, Mexico and the United States resume discussions on Friday over the future of the North American Free Trade Agreement.

headline: As Season Opens, a Fresh Set of Eyes and the Usual Suspects
text: In December, the “human element” in selecting a national champion, so longed for during the 16 years of the Bowl Championship Series’ automatonic algorithm, finally showed up in the College Football Playoff’s third season.

headline: The 10 Games That Will Determine College Football’s Playoff
text: By the end of the season, most of the College Football Playoff contenders’ 12 or 13 games will seem, in retrospect, like insignificant and anonymous blowouts of weaker opposition. But a few games will prove defining for who was beaten, and where and how. These games will be crucial in deciding who gets in and who is left out of the four-team postseason.

headline: A Well-Choreographed Apartment
text: For Kelly Devine, the choreographer of “Come From Away” and “Escape to Margaritaville,” furnishing a home requires as much care as putting on a Broadway show.

headline: In Kelly Devine’s Apartment, Even the Furniture Has to Audition
text: The choreographer Kelly Devine grew up in Los Angeles, and stuck around for the first two decades of her career to stage dances for film, television, videos and commercials. She moved east a dozen years ago to focus on Broadway musicals, and has since worked on “Rock of Ages,” “Rocky,” “Doctor Zhivago” and “Come From Away,” in the process picking up two Tony Award nominations. Next up: “Escape to Margaritaville.”

headline: A Clam Chowder That Tastes Like Summer
text: A traditional chowder of corn, potatoes and clams is like a clambake in a bowl, minus the lobster. Everything bobs about in a delicious broth, highlighting the sweetness of each ingredient.

headline: The August Jobs Numbers Are Weak. Don’t Blame Trump.
text: The details of the August jobs numbers are disappointing, though hardly catastrophic.

headline: When Office Meetings Leave the Office Behind
text: Entrepreneurs have a reputation for working long hours to get their businesses up and running, leading some of their employees to a quick burnout.

headline: A Whirlwind Year for a Workaholic, Mindy Kaling
text: When we last saw “The Mindy Project,” a newly married Mindy Lahiri was gazing out a subway window when a shadow of doubt crossed her face. Which was crazy, because wasn’t this what she’d always wanted?

headline: Russian Election Hacking Efforts, Wider Than Previously Known, Draw Little Scrutiny
text: The calls started flooding in from hundreds of irate North Carolina voters just after 7 a.m. on Election Day last November.

headline: Lasting Merit Found in a Tuberculosis Vaccine Invented a Century Ago
text: Tuberculosis kills almost two million people a year. A perfect vaccine could save many of them, but the one now in use — invented in the 1920s and known as BCG, for Bacillus Calmette-Guérin — has so many flaws that some countries, including the United States, have never adopted it.

headline: Agreement on Construction Workers’ Safety, but Not So Much on Bill
text: When thousands of union workers gathered for a raucous rally near City Hall in late 2015, after a spate of deaths and injuries in construction accidents, they urged local officials to adopt stronger safety measures.

headline: Lattice to Seek Trump’s Approval for Chinese-Backed Buyout
text: The Trump administration will soon face a test of its China economic policy, as a chipmaker plans to appeal to the White House for approval of its proposed sale to a Chinese-backed buyer.

headline: Summer Was Not So Hellish for Commuters at Penn Station
text: After the recent reviews, Amtrak may want to consider producing a sequel to the “summer of hell.”

headline: Under ‘Observation,’ Some Hospital Patients Face Big Bills
text: In April, Nancy Niemi entered Vidant Medical Center in Greenville, N.C., with cardiac problems. She stayed four nights, at one point receiving a coronary stent.

headline: Shelley Berman, Stand-Up Comic Who Skewered Modern Life, Dies at 92
text: Shelley Berman, whose brittle persona and anxiety-ridden observations helped redefine stand-up comedy in the late 1950s and early ’60s, died early Friday morning at his home in Bell Canyon, Calif. He was 92.

headline: ‘Pink Panther’ and ‘Decoy’ Return on Disc
text: It’s a case of good cop, bad cop: The 1957-58 series “Decoy,” an obscure gem from the golden age of network television, has been issued in its entirety on a three-disc set from Film Chest Media Group. And all six movies about the blundering Inspector Clouseau, starring Peter Sellers and directed by Blake Edwards (who also did much of the writing), are out from Shout! Factory as the six-Blu-ray “Pink Panther Film Collection.”

headline: Billy Eichner and Robin Lord Taylor, Living Out Loud (and Quietly)
text: Madonna’s 1998 album, “Ray of Light,” bore many gifts, not least of which was the friendship between Billy Eichner and Robin Lord Taylor.

headline: Library Cards Unlock Film Vaults
text: A few years ago, back when video rental stores were still around but clearly an endangered species (Tower Records had shut down, Blockbuster was in trouble and Netflix was still dealing in DVDs), I was chatting with a friend, a fellow cinephile experiencing an economic downturn. (As it happened, he had worked for Tower.) It was difficult to keep up with classic releases on home video, particularly stuff from the Criterion Collection, he said, but fortunately for him titles would eventually turn up at his local public library. And he didn’t have to wait long for them either, since few people in his New Jersey town (which had once been mine) were keen on art or foreign films.

headline: Harvey, Part II
text: A new state motto?

headline: Shania Twain Walked Out on Top. Now She Wants Back In.
text: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — The last time Shania Twain released an album — the experimental country-but-not-quite opus “Up!” — it sold 874,000 copies in its first week, and went on to receive the Recording Industry Association of America’s diamond certification for 10 million copies sold, her third album in a row to reach that milestone.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here. Download the NYT Cooking app here.

headline: ‘True Detective’ Will Return for a Third Season on HBO
text: It’s actually coming back.

headline: Your Everyday Makeup Questions, Answered
text: Advice from experts on the best ways to apply your daily makeup and, along the way, clear up a few confounding makeup questions.

headline: Women’s Hockey League Will Pay Players for First Time
text: The Canadian Women’s Hockey League will pay players for the first time in its 11-year history beginning this season, the league announced Friday.

headline: 7 Movies to Watch This Labor Day Weekend
text: From “Modern Times” to “Office Space,” here are a few movies about work to sample this weekend.

headline: A Tasting Menu of Yelps and Hums at the Resonant Bodies Festival
text: For a city obsessed with tasting menus and small-plate smorgasbords, there is a fitting festival of experimental vocal music.

headline: U.S. Open Results: Marin Cilic Loses; New Aunt Venus Williams Wins
text: Stay here for live results and analysis from Day 5 of the U.S. Open.

headline: The Best TV Shows and Movies New to Netflix, Amazon and More in December
text: New movies and TV shows are added to streaming platforms each month. Here are the titles we think are most interesting in December.

headline: Cecilia Bartoli, Last Seen With a Beard, May Return to New York
text: SALZBURG, Austria — It has been nearly a decade since the beloved Italian mezzo-soprano Cecilia Bartoli last sang in New York. David Letterman, Jon Stewart and others have been known to grow beards when they’ve left the city’s limelight. But the whiskers Ms. Bartoli was sporting recently weren’t quite of that variety.

headline: Why a 24-Year-Old Chipmaker Is One of Tech’s Hot Prospects
text: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — Engineers at CTA.ai, an imaging-technology start-up in Poland, are trying to popularize a more comfortable alternative to the colonoscopy. To do so, they are using computer chips that are best known to video game fans.

headline: Singing and Chattering: The Week’s 8 Best Classical Music Moments on YouTube
text: Our critics and reporters offer a glimpse of what's delighted them on YouTube. Read the rest of our classical music coverage here.

headline: How Low-Cost Airlines Alter the Economics of Flying
text: For more than three years, the average one-way fare between Detroit and Philadelphia never dipped below $308, and sometimes moved higher, topping $385 at one point.

headline: After Harvey, Houston Showed Up
text: HOUSTON — Houston is sprawling, made of dozens of little Houstons. Bellaire is not Montrose is not the Heights is not Sugar Land, and it’s possible to go years without stepping foot in one community or the other. Each one vibrates on its own frequency.

headline: A Life’s Many Acts Culminate in the Kitchen at NA/NA in Paris
text: When Nathaly Nicolas-Ianniello opened NA/NA in Paris in 2015, not only was it the first time she had ever worked as a chef, but it was her first job in a restaurant. A daring thing for anyone to do, but she was 52, and many of her friends thought she was nuts.

headline: A Controversial Restoration That Wipes Away the Past
text: CHARTRES, France — The pilgrim did not find what he was searching for. As a child, Patrice Bertrand heard his mother recount details of her visit to the shrine of the famous Black Madonna of Chartres Cathedral, 60 miles southwest of Paris. Now Mr. Bertrand, 41, of Nantes, was following in her footsteps. But he was perplexed by what he discovered: “The statue I came to see is not here anymore,” he said. The Black Madonna had become white.

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New on Netflix Canada in September
text: Welcome to Watching, The New York Times’s TV and movie recommendation site.

headline: Mueller Has Early Draft of Trump Letter Giving Reasons for Firing Comey
text: WASHINGTON — The special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, has obtained a letter drafted by President Trump and a top political aide that offered an unvarnished view of Mr. Trump’s thinking in the days before the president fired the F.B.I. director, James B. Comey.

headline: Amy Beach, a Pioneering American Composer, Turns 150
text: Shortly after Antonin Dvorak arrived in the United States in 1892, for a historic visit that resulted in the creation of his “New World” Symphony, he made a cursory remark to a Boston newspaper about gender and the field of music.

headline: Janine Charrat, Ballerina and Choreographer, Dies at 93
text: Janine Charrat, a noted French ballerina who became a major choreographer at a time when few women were engaged in that pursuit and survived a midcareer accident that left her badly burned, died on Tuesday in Paris. She was 93.

headline: Is There a Date-Stamp on the Moving Body?
text: A work by Monica Bill Barnes warrants certain expectations. It will be humorous, it will be fun and, despite your cynical self, you will laugh.

headline: Blunting the Far Right, Merkel Gains as German Election Nears
text: ANNABERG-BUCHHOLZ, Germany — Taking the stage, Chancellor Angela Merkel thanked the thousands of Germans who had turned out at a recent campaign rally, and then leveled her gaze at a small but noisy knot of right-wing protesters yelling and blowing whistles at the back of the square.

headline: Review: ‘Tulip Fever’ Delivers a Wilted Period Piece
text: There’s no way around reviewing “Tulip Fever” without noting that the movie has been buried deeper than a tulip bulb. The Vulture writer Kyle Buchanan has already provided a rundown of the substantial delays in the film’s release, which — for a project once regarded as an Oscar contender — might be taken as a sign of an odor other than floral. This week, Harvey Weinstein, the co-chairman of the Weinstein Company, the film’s distributor, took the extraordinary step of defending the movie in advance with a column for Deadline Hollywood, though it is laced with passive-aggressive barbs like “I know this film’s not perfect, very few are, but it’s a perfectly good time in a movie theater.”

headline: My Son, Off to College
text: To the Editor:

headline: De Blasio Says Donors Were Denied Favors. How Many? Hard to Say.
text: Dogged by investigations into his political fund-raising, Mayor Bill de Blasio promised last year to prove his integrity to New Yorkers by providing concrete examples of campaign contributors who did not get favors from his administration.

headline: Hurricane Irma Looms, but It’s Too Early to Predict Landfall
text: A week after Hurricane Harvey made landfall in Texas, another powerful storm system is looming. But forecasters say it is too early to determine where Hurricane Irma, a Category 3 storm with 115-mile-per-hour winds that was moving west in the Atlantic Ocean early on Friday, would have any impact on land, if at all.

headline: Chinese Firm With Big Stake in Lenovo to Buy Control of Luxembourg Bank
text: LONDON — Legend Holdings, the Chinese company that is the computer manufacturer Lenovo Group’s largest shareholder, said on Friday that it had agreed to buy a 90 percent stake in Banque Internationale à Luxembourg for 1.48 billion euros, or about $1.75 billion.

headline: The Looming Uncertainty for Dreamers Like Me
text: Tuesday was my first day back at school at Baruch College for my senior year. I had been looking forward to starting class again, but it was impossible to pay attention. I was completely distracted by the whiplash of news about whether Donald Trump would end the executive order Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, or DACA, — the policy President Barack Obama announced in 2012 that allowed almost 800,000 immigrant youths like me to step out of the shadows of society.

headline: In Election Interference, It’s What Reporters Didn’t Find That Matters
text: The story started, as many do, with our own confusion.

headline: What to Read About Hurricane Harvey
text: As people begin to comprehend the scope of Hurricane Harvey’s destruction and to plot a path forward, we collected some of the best coverage from around the internet.

headline: An American Abroad
text: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music

headline: What’s Driving Job Growth in Industrial America?
text: President Trump campaigned on reviving the kinds of jobs done in factories, coal mines and oil fields. Since he took office, hiring has indeed ticked upward in these sectors, but is there any connection?

headline: Lil Uzi Vert and a Generation of Rap Stars Looking Beyond Hip-Hop
text: Listen to hip-hop in 2017 and hear the darnedest things. There are rappers who rap in only occasional, seemingly random bursts. There are rappers who mainline the aesthetic and vibrating energy of punk. And there are surrealists who stretch out words and melodies like taffy.

headline: The Yankees’ Judge’s Chambers: A Promotion to Dismiss?
text: There was a game Thursday night when the Yankees’ marketing ploy suddenly was golden; when a real Supreme Court justice, Sonia Sotomayor, donned a black robe and sat in the Judge’s Chambers at the Bronx stadium to cheer on Aaron Judge.

headline: Better Planning for Inevitable Disasters
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Cost of Hurricane Harvey: Only One Recent Storm Comes Close
text: Comparing more than 200 billion-dollar natural disasters since 1980.

headline: Rock’s Not Dead, It’s Ruled by Women: The Round-Table Conversation
text: For years now, we, the pop music team of The New York Times — Jon Caramanica, Joe Coscarelli, Caryn Ganz and Jon Pareles — have wondered where exactly the guitars went. While there’s never been a shortage of quote-unquote traditional rock bands — say, a mostly male, mostly white four-piece — their cultural impact has continued to wane in the face of increasingly diverse musical tactics, distribution networks and messengers.

headline: Vanguard Speaks Softly but Carries a Big Stick
text: The activist hedge-fund manager Paul Singer recently warned that the rise of so-called passive investing risked distorting markets and “devouring capitalism.”

headline: If Not for ‘The Jinx,’ Robert Durst May Have Avoided Murder Charges
text: Robert A. Durst’s Los Angeles trial for the murder of his friend Susan Berman is still a year away. But for the last seven months, testimony in a series of “conditional hearings” has battered Mr. Durst, the eccentric scion of a New York real estate family. Despite his frail demeanor, witnesses have testified, over the years he has had episodes of violence, and often a revolver in his possession.

headline: Amid Allegations, a Call for Essex County College’s Board to Resign
text: NEWARK — A group of New Jersey religious leaders called for the resignation of the entire board of Essex County College Thursday and for federal and state investigations into allegations of financial malfeasance and undue political influence at the institution, which is in danger of losing its accreditation after years of mismanagement.

headline: Pope Francis Sought Psychoanalysis at 42, According to Book
text: ROME — At 42, Pope Francis had weekly sessions with a psychoanalyst for about six months “to clarify some things,” according to excerpts from a new book by a French sociologist scheduled to be published next week.

headline: 10 Things to Do in NYC Now
text: The latest side project from the popular American Ballet Theater principal dancer Daniil Simkin involves real-time motion sensors; costumes by Dior; and projections by his father, Dmitrij, also an accomplished ballet dancer. A commission by the Works & Process Rotunda Project, this 30-minute work — scheduled to be performed twice nightly, at 8 and 9:30 p.m., on Monday and Tuesday — features Mr. Simkin, the Ballet Theater soloist Cassandra Trenary, the Hubbard Street dancer Ana Lopez and Brett Conway in juicy choreography by the Hubbard Street house choreographer, Alejandro Cerrudo. With observers watching from above, standing along the Guggenheim’s spiraling ramps, the dancers will tangle with each other and their own shadows, which, thanks to technology, will seem to have developed minds of their own. BRIAN SCHAEFER

headline: Helping Women Over 50 Face Their Financial Fears
text: Ronni Ginott was at a New Year’s Day party in 2003 when her husband, David, had a heart attack and died on the spot, at 58.

headline: Rome Survived Caligula. Will America Survive Trump?
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Nashville Statement Is an Attack on L.G.B.T. Christians
text: This week, an influential group of evangelical Christians publicly doubled down on intolerance in a message about lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people that represents a renewed commitment to open bigotry.

headline: What if I Bombed at My Own Wedding?
text: Any nerves I had leading up to my wedding manifested less as a case of cold feet than as a flare-up of preshow jitters. There were, of course, the predictable stresses: Did everyone receive their invitations? Will my mother’s elderly cousins dance to “The Thong Song”?

headline: Matchesfashion.com Sells Majority Stake to Apax After Fierce Bidding War
text: LONDON — Matchesfashion.com, the British luxury e-commerce group that began life as a single bricks-and-mortar boutique before growing into one of the most powerful online players in the global high-fashion market, has a new majority shareholder after a fierce bidding war.

headline: Michael Cromartie, Who Guided Journalists on Religion, Dies at 67
text: Michael Cromartie, who shepherded a generation of journalists toward more informed coverage of religion’s evolving junction with politics and public policy, died on Monday at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 67.

headline: ‘Narcos’ Season 3 Premiere: Life Without Pablo
text: Welcome back, everyone. The last time we checked in on “Narcos,” Pablo Escobar was bleeding out on a Colombian rooftop. It was the logical (and historically accurate) end to two seasons of drama and violence.

headline: Trump Says Decision on ‘Dreamers’ Program Will Come Soon
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Friday said he would announce a decision by Tuesday on whether he will end the Obama-era program that shields young undocumented immigrants from deportation, declaring, “We love the Dreamers” even as his White House grappled with how to wind down their legal status.

headline: Dakota Plan to Bury, Not Burn, ‘Scaffold’ Sculpture
text: MINNEAPOLIS — The remains of “Scaffold,” a sculpture that prompted outrage among Native Americans this summer when it was placed in the Minneapolis Sculpture Garden, will be buried in a secret location in Minnesota, according to Ron Leith, a Dakota representative.

headline: Retrieving Gold, and More, From Wastewater
text: Q. Are the heavy metals removed from wastewater valuable?

headline: Led by a Vietnam War Opus, a Rich Season of Documentaries
text: Watch a lot of television documentaries and docu-series, as I do, and you might have started to feel over the last few years as if a handful of subjects were monopolizing filmmakers’ attention. Syria. Shootings of black people by police officers. Prison conditions and the plight of ex-convicts. Stress and suicide among military veterans.

headline: Polarizing Former New York Detective Will Be Honored by His Peers
text: If they know him at all, most New Yorkers know Louis Scarcella as the once-renowned and now retired detective whose reputation for solving murders has been battered in recent years by serial allegations of misconduct.

headline: Turkey’s President Calls U.S. Indictments of His Guards a ‘Scandal’
text: Turkey’s president denounced what he called the “scandalous” American judicial system on Friday, responding to new indictments of his bodyguards over a brawl during his visit to Washington in May.

headline: For Car Buyers, Larger Inventories May Mean Good Deals
text: The end of summer is often a good time to find deals on new car purchases — and that is especially true this year, given that car sales have slowed and dealers are eager to make sales.

headline: New America, a Google-Funded Think Tank, Faces Backlash for Firing a Google Critic
text: WASHINGTON — The head of an influential think tank funded by Google is grappling with a mounting backlash — including from her own scholars and donors — over the firing of a leading critic of the tech giant.

headline: What 8 Art Fans Wore to a Hamptons Opening
text: Auto Body, a scrappy artist collective in Bellport, N.Y., unveiled a new exhibition this summer. Commissioned by the Parrish Art Museum, the works include cheeky road signs like “Hold Your Horses” and “Takes Two to Canoe,” erected along the traffic-clogged stretch of Montauk Highway between Bellport and Water Mill. To celebrate the project, artists, weekenders and others gathered on Aug. 12 at Bush Farms and Museum.

headline: Louise Hay, Widely Read Self-Help Author, Dies at 90
text: Louise Hay, who from a 1984 best seller built a self-help publishing empire that has attracted millions of devotees with its messages about the power of thought and attitude, died on Wednesday at her home in San Diego. She was 90.

headline: Cowboys’ Elliott and Players’ Union Sue to Void Any Suspension
text: Less than a week before the N.F.L. season begins, the league and one its most prominent players, Ezekiel Elliott of the Dallas Cowboys, have set the stage for a down-to-the-wire court battle over his six-game suspension related to a domestic violence incident.

headline: The Playlist: U2 Dances Into Darkness and 11 More New Songs
text: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos — and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. This week, N.O.R.E. and Pharrell Williams team up again, tributes to Thelonious Monk start to pour in, and Robert Plant unleashes a dark vision.

headline: Juicero, Start-Up With a $700 Juicer and Top Investors, Shuts Down
text: MONTEREY, Calif. — From the moment it started, Juicero stood out as a symbol of Silicon Valley’s insular excess.

headline: White House to Ask for $14.5 Billion Down Payment for Harvey Relief
text: WASHINGTON — The White House is asking Congress for more than $14 billion as a down payment on Hurricane Harvey recovery efforts, sending Republican leaders a request late Friday for $7.8 billion in immediate aid that will be quickly followed by a request for another $6.7 billion, officials said.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What We’re Reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

headline: A Taste of Indian Nostalgia Finds an Eager Audience
text: EDISON, N.J. — For anyone who grew up in India during the second half of the 20th century, ice cream is inseparable from the name Kwality.

headline: Canada Letter: Debating Sir John A. and a Remote Town Stranded
text: The legacy of Sir John A. Macdonald, the first prime minister of Canada, has become the subject of debate in light of his attitudes and policies toward indigenous people. Kingston, Ontario, seemed like the obvious place to go to explore the issue. Macdonald grew up there, represented it in Parliament until his death in 1891 and is buried there.

headline: Open Thread: This Week in Style News
text: Each week, the Open Thread newsletter will offer a look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. The latest newsletter appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Alexandr Dolgopolov Wins, but Is Grilled About a Suspicious Loss
text: A dozen reporters crowded around a small table Wednesday afternoon to talk to Alexandr Dolgopolov after his five-set victory over Jan-Lennard Struff in the first round of the United States Open.

headline: Astros, Best in A.L., Bulk Up Pitching by Acquiring Verlander
text: The Houston Astros reported to spring training believing they were the best team in the American League. They have proved it ever since, arriving in September with the A.L.’s best record, at 80-53. But even in March, their starting rotation seemed thin. Jeff Luhnow, their general manager, had been unwilling — not unable — to trade for an ace last winter.

headline: See Harvey’s Path From a Helicopter
text: Get a 360-degree view of the flooding and damage caused by Tropical Storm Harvey in and around Houston and Port Arthur, Tex.

headline: Texas, Russia, Uhuru Kenyatta: Your Friday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Karoly Makk, Acclaimed Hungarian Filmmaker, Dies at 91
text: Karoly Makk, a leading Hungarian director who was honored at the Cannes Film Festival in 1971 for “Love,” the story of one family’s survival under his country’s repressive Stalinist rule, then nominated four years later for an Academy Award for best foreign-language film, for  “Cats’ Play,” died on Aug. 30. He was 91.

headline: Handling of Police Killing Spurs Grand Jury Inquiry Into Prosecutor
text: ALBANY — The New York State attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, intends to impanel a grand jury this month to investigate a district attorney in relation to the fatal police shooting in Troy, N.Y., of an unarmed motorist in 2016.

headline: Serena Williams Gives Birth to a Baby Girl
text: Serena Williams has given birth to a girl, according to the United States Open’s official Twitter account and her coach.

headline: Judge Throws Out Most Serious Charges in Penn State Hazing Case
text: A Pennsylvania judge on Friday dismissed the most serious charges against eight Penn State fraternity members indicted in the hazing death of a 19-year-old student, sharply and suddenly defanging prosecutors and setting the stage for a new legal battle in the high-profile case.

headline: Data Shows Mayweather-McGregor Was a Pay-Per-View Juggernaut
text: The blockbuster fight between the boxer Floyd Mayweather Jr. and the mixed martial arts fighter Conor McGregor last Saturday has a “very good shot” at being the top-grossing fighting event of all time, the Showtime Sports executive in charge of it said Friday.

headline: Friday Night Music: Sylvan Esso, “Die Young”
text: No column today, and radio silence, because I’m traveling (forum at Universidad Autonoma de Nuevo Leon, talking Trump and NAFTA). But I have time for a quick entry — this live version (with a Mountain Man reunion!) has been going around my brain for days.

headline: A Long-Pursued ISIS Preacher Is Finally Charged in New York
text: WASHINGTON — For two decades, Abdullah el-Faisal has preached jihad, on the streets and online, first promoting the grim theology of Al Qaeda and then endorsing the Islamic State. Imprisoned in England and later deported from Kenya to his native Jamaica, he has in recent years kept up his internet proselytizing from his home near Kingston. His influence has turned up repeatedly in major terrorism cases.

headline: Forceful Chief of Staff Grates on Trump, and the Feeling Is Mutual
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump was in an especially ornery mood after staff members gently suggested he refrain from injecting politics into day-to-day issues of governing after last month’s raucous rally in Arizona, and he responded by lashing out at the most senior aide in his presence.

headline: Jim Rice Weighs In on C.C. Sabathia-Eduardo Nunez Feud
text: In the annals of the sometimes ferocious Yankees-Boston Red Sox rivalry, there have been some memorable matchups and more than a few brawls.

headline: Stranded ISIS Convoy Symbolizes Militants’ Stalled Campaign
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Islamic State militant, his AK-47 cradled between his legs, crouched next to the driver in the front of the bus, near a placard in the windshield that read B-9, which stood for bus No. 9 out of 17. The flash of a camera in the early dawn light showed him to be smiling broadly.

headline: Tal Afar After Liberation From ISIS: Battered but Still Standing
text: TAL AFAR, Iraq — An airstrike left a crater the size of a tennis court in one neighborhood. Artillery punched a gaping hole in the minaret of the city’s main mosque. Some buildings were leveled.

headline: A Turning Point for South Vietnam?
text: Tomorrow marks the 50th anniversary of Vietnam’s most democratic election.

headline: The Older the Better in Professional Tennis These Days
text: The future of men’s tennis has appeared to be previewing itself during the first week at the United States Open. Just how far into the future is anyone’s guess.

headline: For Vulnerable Older Adults, a Harrowing Sense of Being Trapped
text: HOUSTON — A Holocaust survivor waded waist-deep in flood water. Dozens of people were trapped in a 14-story residence for seniors. A disabled man sat alone at home, without the aide who usually helps him, watching the water rise and unsure if anyone would come.

headline: Waiting for a Perfect Protest?
text: Media outlets and commentators representing a range of political persuasions have called attention to recent outbreaks of violence in Berkeley, Calif., Boston and other locations where anti-racist and anti-fascist demonstrators have gathered. Intentionally or not, they have often promoted a false equivalency between groups that advocate white supremacy and those that seek to eliminate it.

headline: Venus Williams, a Newly Minted Aunt, Keeps Her Focus on the Business at Hand
text: The news came before Venus Williams stepped onto the court for her third-round match Friday afternoon at the United States Open. Big news, about her sister Serena.

headline: Where Harvey Hit Hardest Up and Down the Texas Coast
text: Over 150,000 properties in Texas have been affected by Hurricane Harvey, based on preliminary estimates by the Federal Emergency Management Agency.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Little Effort to Investigate in States Targeted by Election Hacking
text: “We don’t know if any of the problems were an accident, or the random problems you get with computer systems, or whether it was a local hacker, or actual malfeasance by a sovereign nation-state.”

headline: Water Damage From Hurricane Harvey Extended Far Beyond Flood Zones
text: About 40 percent of flooded buildings were in areas considered a “minimal flood hazard.”

headline: Denis Shapovalov, 18, Advances to Fourth Round at U.S. Open
text: Denis Shapovalov’s high-flying and improbable run at the United States Open continued Friday as he advanced to the fourth round of only his second Grand Slam main-draw event.

headline: How to Regulate Artificial Intelligence
text: The technology entrepreneur Elon Musk recently urged the nation’s governors to regulate artificial intelligence “before it’s too late.” Mr. Musk insists that artificial intelligence represents an “existential threat to humanity,” an alarmist view that confuses A.I. science with science fiction. Nevertheless, even A.I. researchers like me recognize that there are valid concerns about its impact on weapons, jobs and privacy. It’s natural to ask whether we should develop A.I. at all.

headline: If You Want to MAGA, Save DACA
text: What is it, really, that makes a country great?

headline: Corrections: September 2, 2017
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Where There’s Smoke, There’s a Conspiracy Theory at a Russian Consulate
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Amid rare extreme heat in San Francisco, it was unusual to see black smoke billowing from a chimney on Friday — not to mention that it was coming from the Russian Consulate, the day after the Trump administration ordered it closed.

headline: Utah Nurse Handcuffed After Refusing to Draw Patient’s Blood
text: The body camera video from a Salt Lake City police officer in an emergency room at University of Utah Hospital was rife with tension.

headline: In Beaumont, Tex., Hopscotching for Food, Water and Shelter
text: BEAUMONT, Tex. — Carrie Chambliss climbed into her husband’s truck on Friday and drove a winding route some 70 miles, plowing through deep water, to get from her home in Mauriceville to a grocery store in Beaumont that had “barely anything” left.

headline: The Second Video Ever Shown on MTV
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Well, this was a lot of fun. Erik Agard is back with a puzzle that not only debuts a whopping 11 entries, but also contains a lot of really good stuff and devious cluing.

headline: U.S. Stumbles in Qualifying on Night Mexico Clinches Place in World Cup
text: HARRISON, N.J. — If a sense of inevitability about qualifying for next year’s World Cup had begun to take hold for the United States national team under Bruce Arena, a feeling that he had reset the team’s course since replacing the team’s previous coach, Jurgen Klinsmann, that aura vanished Friday night.

headline: A Tennis Player Rises in the Rankings After a Terrible Fall
text: On a summer evening six years ago, the Italian tennis player Stefano Travaglia walked from his family’s sixth-floor apartment in the town of Ascoli Piceno near the Adriatic coast to the floor below. He needed to pick up some tennis shirts onto which an elderly neighbor had sewn sponsor patches for him. He bypassed the building’s elevator for the short trip, taking the stairs.

headline: The Summer of Love’s Dispiriting Fall
text: THE Summer of Love began with a burst of flower power. On June 1, 1967, the Beatles released “Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band,” and the horticulture was nearly as impressive as the music. In the foreground of the album cover, the flowers spelled out the band’s name, and formed other shapes nearby — a guitar here, a star there. A daisy grew from John’s shoulder, a natural epaulet.

headline: Catcher Derek Norris Suspended for Season Under Domestic Violence Policy
text: The free-agent catcher Derek Norris was suspended Friday for the rest of the season for violating Major League Baseball’s domestic violence policy.

headline: Eduardo Nunez, Once a Friend to the Yankees, Is Now a Thorn in Their Side
text: During Eduardo Nunez’s four seasons as a Yankee, he was part team mascot, part punch line.

headline: Maybe Colin Kaepernick Is Just Not That Good
text: Whether or not Colin Kaepernick plays another down in the N.F.L., I’m going to say that he can achieve more off a football field than he — or anyone else in the sport — can achieve on one.

headline: Primary Choices for the New York City Council
text: Here are endorsements in five competitive races.

headline: Seahawks Acquire Sheldon Richardson From the Jets
text: The Seattle Seahawks acquired defensive tackle Sheldon Richardson from the Jets on Friday in exchange for wide receiver Jermaine Kearse and a second-round draft pick, bolstering a defense that was already considered among the best in the N.F.L.

headline: A Polished Hotel in Asbury Park Is New Center of Gravity
text: From $125.

headline: Man Barred From Open Last Year Is Arrested After Returning
text: The United States Tennis Association announced on Friday the arrest of an Estonian man who violated a no-trespassing order by returning to the United States Open after having been ejected from the tournament last year.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Humans of New York’ and ‘A Monster Calls’
text: Brandon Stanton’s popular photography project comes to Facebook’s new streaming platform. And a family drama about a 12-year-old boy and a monstrous tree arrives on HBO.

headline: The First Count of Fentanyl Deaths in 2016: Up 540% in Three Years
text: The first governmental account of nationwide drug deaths in 2016 shows overdose deaths growing even faster than previously thought.

headline: In Indonesia, 3 Muslim Girls Fight for Their Right to Play Heavy Metal
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — The three teenage girls — shy and even seeming slightly embarrassed as they peer out from their Islamic head scarves — do not look much like a heavy metal band.

headline: Town After Town Under Water in the 100 Miles From Houston to Beaumont
text: Hurricane Harvey left residents of many small towns stranded.

headline: 'Today We Should Not Be Blue- or Red-State People’
text: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment. Some comments were edited for length and clarity.

headline: In Venezuela, Cooking With Firewood as Currency Collapses
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Food shortages were already common in Venezuela, so Tabata Soler knew painfully well how to navigate the country’s black market stalls to get basics like eggs and sugar.

headline: Rosa Parks House in Berlin Has a Ticket Home to America
text: LONDON — In a backyard in Berlin, a ramshackle house that was once a haven for the civil rights pioneer Rosa Parks is preparing for its third life — back in the United States.

headline: Silicon Valley Courts Brand-Name Teachers, Raising Ethics Issues
text: MAPLETON, N.D. — One of the tech-savviest teachers in the United States teaches third grade here at Mapleton Elementary, a public school with about 100 students in the sparsely populated plains west of Fargo.

headline: ‘Dear Sugars’: In the Shadow of Damaged Parents
text: Her father had cheated, and her mother blamed herself and the children for his infidelities. “She said if we were better behaved and he’d had a better home life, he would have never cheated on us,” this week’s letter writer recalls. "She told my sister and me that we were not attractive enough to keep a man.”

headline: Celine Dion Loves You. And You. And You.
text: Annick Chenard, 38, has seen Celine Dion in concert 21 times and also has a large tattoo of Ms. Dion’s face and flowing hair on her right shoulder. She recently spent a whole day out on a Montreal street with a fold-up chair and a poncho, waiting for a slim chance to meet her queen.

headline: EJ Johnson Is ‘Not Just Some Other Rich Girl’
text: “Today we are talking about breaking boundaries,” EJ Johnson declared from the stage of Beautycon, a two-day cosmetics festival held in August at the Los Angeles Convention Center. The 25-year-old son of Magic Johnson was moderating a panel called “The Gender Revolution,” and he was dressed for the part: black silk pants, crop top, sleeveless duster.

headline: Want to Have a Good Day? Try Making the Bed First
text: When Adm. William H. McRaven, retired, was stationed in Afghanistan, his days were filled with chaos and unpredictability. “We could have soldiers dying and the horror of civilian casualties,” he said.

headline: New York City Parks in the Summer: Romance, Games and a Performance for a Dying Tree
text: Parks in New York offer one of the city’s most coveted and valuable amenities: space. “You very rarely have room to spread out and not think about getting in somebody’s way,” said Daniel Arnold, a photographer who spent two months capturing moments in New York City’s open spaces. “There’s this psychological relief to them.”

headline: Get Ready for Technological Upheaval by Expecting the Unimagined
text: Self-driving vehicles could upend the transportation sector and eliminate a million or more jobs. Algorithms that decode M.R.I.s put a whole medical subfield at risk. And the list of professions and sectors soon to be obsolete grows steadily by the day.

headline: Give Up Prosecco to Save Your Teeth? British Claim Riles Italy
text: ROME — A storm in a wineglass has erupted between Italy and Britain after some British dentists claimed this past week that prosecco, the bubbly North Italian wine, causes chronic tooth decay.

headline: Eid al-Adha: Muslims Around the World Celebrate Holy Festival
text: Millions of Muslims across the globe — including in countries like India, Indonesia, Turkey, Russia and Pakistan — are celebrating Eid al-Adha, Islam’s most revered observance.

headline: L’Oréal Drops Transgender Model Over Comments on Race
text: A transgender activist and model was dropped from a L’Oréal ad campaign because of comments she made on social media about race, the company said on Friday.

headline: Video of Police Officer Knocking Down Woman and Child Incenses China
text: BEIJING — Twenty-two seconds of real-life police drama have riveted and divided many in China over officers’ powers to use force against irate residents — including a woman clutching an infant.

headline: After Harvey, a Return Home in High Water
text: Days after a storm battered Houston, a family made an emotional return through waist-high water to see their flooded home and collect their belongings.

headline: He Had Her at ‘We the People’
text: Melissa Rose Alpert and Trevor Douglas Mills are to be married Sept. 3 at Rock Island Lake Club, an events space in Sparta, N.J. Mike Schellhammer, a friend of the groom who is affiliated with American Marriage Ministries, is to officiate.

headline: Finding Comfort in Each Other, and the Unknown
text: Kelly Anthoula Love and Hristos George Karavoulias were married Sept. 2 in Lowell, Mass. Rev. Gregory Christakos performed the ceremony at the Transfiguration Greek Orthodox Church.

headline: Stranger Than Fiction: What Happened After the Bookstore
text: Molly Higgins Fischer married Samuel Chandler MacLaughlin Sept. 2 in South Dartmouth, Mass. Nina MacLaughlin, the groom’s sister, who received a one-day marriage designation from the state of Massachusetts, officiated at the home of the groom’s father and his partner, Pamela A. Murray.

headline: Human Toll of Harvey Comes Into View as Waters Recede
text: One couple had just another stop or two in their pickup truck, a check on an elderly uncle. A 60-year-old woman had just lain down for a much-needed nap. An 8-year-old boy was riding in a van with his extended family in search of higher ground.

headline: One Week After Harvey, Texas Residents Exhausted, Still Stranded
text: HOUSTON — A week after Texas was slammed by Hurricane Harvey, this region was still engulfed in crisis on Saturday, with weary residents of Houston searching for ways to repair swamped homes and salvage possessions even as others faced new orders to evacuate. In cities and small towns to the east, thousands of others remained stranded by rising waters and were still without dry shelter.

headline: The Popcast Answers Your Questions About Beyoncé, Music Videos and More
text: The Popcast is hosted by Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic for The New York Times. It covers the latest in pop music criticism, trends and news.

headline: For One Family in Houston, an Overwhelming Start to Recovery
text: HOUSTON — She couldn’t sleep. Not now.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — Like our constructors, I no longer own a Magic 8 Ball, but I had one when I was a child. When you are young and innocent and hope against hope for something to come true, you will go to extraordinary lengths to confirm that hope.

headline: Police and Protesters Clash Over Disappearance of Argentine Activist
text: BUENOS AIRES — The disappearance of an indigenous rights activist in Argentina spurred violent clashes between demonstrators and the police on Friday and has raised dark memories of forced disappearances during the country’s dictatorship.

headline: ISIS Is on Its Heels, but Fighting to the Death
text: ABOARD THE U.S.S. NIMITZ, in the Persian Gulf — A few days ago, Capt. Mike Spencer of the Navy rocketed off the flight deck of an aircraft carrier in his F-18 to provide air support for Iraqi troops advancing on the dusty city of Tal Afar, one of the Islamic State’s last strongholds.

headline: Minnesota Finds a Way to Slow Soaring Health Premiums
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Last fall, as consumers in Minnesota were facing health insurance rate increases of 50 percent or more, Gov. Mark Dayton, a Democrat, said the Affordable Care Act was “no longer affordable to increasing numbers of people.” The state’s top insurance regulator said the Minnesota market was “on the verge of collapse.”

headline: Trump Returns to Texas, With Words of Encouragement and Triumph
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump urged onlookers at a Houston shelter to “have a good time” on Saturday — and appeared to take his own advice during a daylong Gulf Coast tour that blurred the line between bucking up a battered region and taking an early victory lap.

headline: Ivan Lendl, Open Champion, Pushes the Benefits of Group Training
text: Patrick Kypson knows the precise punishment — including how many steps on the VersaClimber, an extreme aerobic exercise machine — he must endure for every transgression he commits during a practice session with Ivan Lendl, the three-time United States Open champion who helps oversee Kypson’s development as a tennis player.

headline: ‘Endless Stream’ of Rohingya Flee Military Offensive
text: “By far the worst thing that I've ever seen.” The New York Times reporter Hannah Beech describes a huge exodus of civilians into Bangladesh after a new military offensive against Rohingya Muslims in Myanmar.

headline: Desperate Rohingya Flee Myanmar on Trail of Suffering: ‘It Is All Gone’
text: REZU AMTALI, Bangladesh — They stumble down muddy ravines and flooded creeks through miles of hills and jungle in Bangladesh, and thousands more come each day, in a line stretching to the monsoon-darkened horizon.

headline: We Don’t Deny Harvey, So Why Deny Climate Change?
text: Imagine that after the 9/11 attacks, the conversation had been limited to the tragedy in Lower Manhattan, the heroism of rescuers and the high heels of the visiting first lady — without addressing the risks of future terrorism.

headline: The Real Battle Begins: Mr. Macron vs. the Labor Code
text: Since his spectacular victory in France’s presidential race in May on a promise of a new kind of politics, Emmanuel Macron has had a rocky ride. The military chief of staff quit in anger over budget cuts; the president endured ridicule over how much he spent on his makeup; he has been accused of being aloof; his popularity ratings have plummeted. All that, however, is just a prelude to the real battle.

headline: The Best Era for Working Women Was 20 Years Ago
text: The working woman was everywhere in 1980s and 1990s pop culture: The tough single gal Murphy Brown ran the news on TV every week. Dolly Parton in “9 to 5,” Melanie Griffith in “Working Girl,” and the ominously coldhearted mother in “Mrs. Doubtfire.”

headline: The Real Campus Scourge
text: Across the country, college freshmen are settling into their new lives and grappling with something that doesn’t compete with protests and political correctness for the media’s attention, something that no one prepared them for, something that has nothing to do with being “snowflakes” and everything to do with being human.

headline: The False Promises in President Trump’s Tax Plan
text: As they return to Washington this week from their August recess, House Republicans on the Ways and Means Committee have their work cut out for them. Their job is to draft a major tax-cut bill for Congress to pass, ideally by year-end, to avoid closing out 2017 without a single big legislative win. The policy objective is to steeply cut tax rates for businesses and wealthy individuals. The political aim, and the point of President Trump’s speech last Wednesday, is to persuade the men and women in the Trump working-class base that a tax cut for the wealthy would be good for them, too.

headline: Don’t Suspend Students. Empathize.
text: To his teachers at Ridgeway High School in Memphis, Jason Okonofua was a handful. During class, his mind drifted and he would lose the thread of the lesson. He slouched at his desk and dozed off.

headline: Can Melania Trump Rise Above It All?
text: We are not going to dwell on Melania Trump’s flying to flood-ravaged Texas in stilettos, or sneakers, here. But nature abhors a vacuum, and the first lady’s fans and critics focus on her costumes in part because, so far, that’s about all they see of Melania Trump. In the back-to-work spirit of Labor Day, let’s reflect on Mrs. Trump’s plans as first lady now that she’s settled in the White House and Barron, her only child, heads back to school.

headline: Right-Wing Books, Wrong Answers
text: Normal human beings read thrillers or romances on vacation; newspaper columnists assign themselves political polemics.

headline: Kenyans Celebrate Court’s Ruling to Nullify Election
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The chief justice of Kenya’s Supreme Court, David Maraga, is a Seventh-day Adventist who refuses to preside over a court case on a Saturday. Once accused of corruption, he went on live television and swore on the Bible that he had never taken a bribe.

headline: Houston Needs a Hand
text: HOUSTON — I am sure that by now many of you have seen the heartening pictures of the countless volunteers here in Houston, lining up to help out in the wake of Hurricane Harvey, kayaking to the rescue, opening their homes to strangers, feeding the hungry from their own kitchens. The scenes are even more moving in person, when you see the pickup trucks piled high with plastic bags of donations causing traffic jams around the George R. Brown Convention Center, and still more people coming in on foot, bearing boxes of diapers, dog food, bar soap, pillows, blankets and virtually anything else a human in an emergency could use.

headline: Upsets and Injuries Leave the U.S. Open Men’s Bracket Wide Open
text: When fifth-seeded Marin Cilic lost Friday afternoon to 29th-seeded Diego Schwartzman, players took notice of who was — and who was not — left around them in the draw.

headline: Stephen Miller Is the Enemy of My Dreams
text: I am a peaceable person. By that I mean I avoid conflict and also I’m quite lazy. People generally appeal to me. I can see their good side. I sometimes have fleeting antagonisms: toward a waitress I feel is being too performative in her friendship with a coffee shop regular, or that woman on the subway eating a plum really loudly. But in general, I have a smiley face and at the risk of sounding bonkers, I make friends with almost everyone I come across. What I’m missing, I’ve come to realize after a summer of cookouts and heart-to-hearts and hiking trips, is an enemy.

headline: ‘The New Washington’: Roger Stone
text: Note from January 25, 2019: Roger Stone was arrested by the F.B.I. on Friday in connection to the special counsel’s investigation and was charged with seven counts, including obstruction of an official proceeding, making false statements and witness tampering. Read the latest here.

headline: Jim Bridenstine to Be Nominated by Trump to Lead NASA
text: Representative Jim Bridenstine, Republican of Oklahoma, will be nominated by President Trump to serve as NASA’s next administrator, the White House said on Friday night.

headline: What Climate Scientists Want You to See in the Floodwaters
text: STANFORD, Calif. — Like most Americans this week, we have been transfixed by the still unfolding disaster in Houston and coastal Texas, described on the airwaves as “unprecedented” and “beyond anything experienced.”

headline: Yankees Beat Red Sox as Matt Holliday Returns From the D.L. With a Blast
text: On July 15, Matt Holliday hit a home run off Boston Red Sox closer Craig Kimbrel in the ninth inning at Fenway Park, sending the game into extra innings. It wound up lasting 16, and Holliday played every one of them.

headline: As Bike-Sharing Brings Out Bad Manners, China Asks, What’s Wrong With Us?
text: BEIJING — Liu Lijing, a mechanic in Beijing, does not usually pay much attention to manners. He does not mind when people blast loud music, and he strolls the alleyways near his home in a tank top stained with grease. But when a stranger recently ditched a bicycle in the bushes outside his door, Mr. Liu was irate.

headline: Goodbye, Yosemite. Hello, What?
text: HOTELS generally don’t figure prominently in my imagination, but Yosemite Valley does, and so does the glamorous Ahwahnee Hotel. When my father took me on Yosemite climbing trips in the 1980s, we never stayed at the Ahwahnee — it costs a fortune — but Dad always brought clean dress shirts so that we could hang out in the Ahwahnee’s kitschy Indian Room Bar before we slept illegally under the evergreens.

headline: Is Trump Really Pro-Worker?
text: Even though Donald Trump is a flamboyant billionaire, many blue-collar voters embraced him as the presidential candidate who would lift them out of their economic rut. “I will bring jobs back and get wages up,” Mr. Trump said last summer, vowing to get tough on trade, Mexico and China.

headline: In El Salvador, ‘Girls Are a Problem’
text: SAN SALVADOR — I don’t want to go back to El Salvador. I felt afraid as a woman there more than in any other country in Latin America. I realized I had entered hostile territory while chatting with the taxi driver who picked me up at the airport, the first Salvadoran man I met. He told me he had a baby, a little darling called J. J., and showed me a photo.

headline: Long List of Top Democrats Have 2020, and Money, on Their Minds
text: WASHINGTON — Aides to Senator Kamala Harris of California say that her fund-raisers in Martha’s Vineyard and the Hamptons this summer have been all about helping Democrats in 2018. Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s allies say his new political group is building an email list so he can communicate directly with his supporters about the future of the party and the country. And Representative Tim Ryan of Ohio says he has been traveling to Iowa and New Hampshire in part because “I like being out around the country.”

headline: Outlawing War? It Actually Worked
text: If you were to ask historians to name the most foolish treaty ever signed, odds are good that they would name the  Kellogg-Briand Pact of 1928. The pact, which was joined by 63 nations, outlawed war. Ending war is an absurdly ambitious goal. To think it could be done by treaty? Not just absurd but dangerously naïve.

headline: Instagram Your Leftovers: History Depends on It
text: I am a culinary historian, and scrolling through the endless food on Instagram makes me hungry. No, not for the fresh-baked sourdough rolls nestled so prettily in a linen napkin or that jaunty tumbler of strawberry mousse sporting its shiny green sprigs of mint. They look delicious, but what really makes my mouth water is the thought of all the stories behind them — everything that happened in the kitchen before you picked up your phone and clicked.

headline: The Moral Debate Over Statues
text: To the Editor:

headline: United Kingdom
text: SUNDAY PUZZLE — For about a month, my dog, Jade — known to most as The Extremely Spunky Border terrier, or ESBT — enjoyed an unusual friendship. Border terriers were bred to rid their Scottish ancestors’ households of rodents, and they still “go to ground,” as it is called, but Jade has never shown any particular interest in her genetic lot. She’s a lover, not a fighter, so when the rabbit came knocking, Jade’s reaction was: “Cool! Another four-legged friend to play with!”

headline: Amid Nuclear Tensions, Trump Mulls Exit From South Korea Trade Deal
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump is considering pulling out of a major trade agreement with South Korea as he tries to fulfill get-tough campaign pledges on international trade. But he has not yet made a final decision, two senior administration officials said Saturday.

headline: A Crude Rant Gets Fognini Booted From the Open — and Good Riddance
text: One of the biggest victories at the United States Open on Saturday didn’t happen on a tennis court. It was even sweeter than a great sports performance, and much more satisfying, too.

headline: No Madonna. No Geena Davis. But Still in a League of Their Own.
text: SOUTH ELGIN, Ill. — Strike one. “You swing like a girl!” the pitcher barked, heckling yet another player at the plate. Sonja Bushnick of the Rockford Peaches lifted her wooden bat again. She passed on one ball and fouled off another. On the next pitch she hit a short pop-up that the pitcher caught with ease. He laughed at her.

headline: North Korea Claims to Have Developed a Missile-Ready Hydrogen Bomb
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said on Sunday that it has developed a hydrogen bomb “with super explosive power” to be mounted on its intercontinental ballistic missile.

headline: Quotation of the Day: In Venezuela, That Empty Feeling
text: “Bolívars are like ice cubes now. If you’re going to go to the fridge and take one, it’s something you have to use right now, because soon it’s going to be gone.”

headline: Canadian Teenager, Headed to the Fourth Round, Gives U.S. Open a Jolt
text: On Saturday morning, Denis Shapovalov and two of his childhood friends, Jan Alafriz and Jonathan Soriano, drank tea in a dimly lit lounge at their hotel in Manhattan. A woman and her daughter approached the table and asked Shapovalov to autograph the cast on the daughter’s forearm.

headline: Uneven Pliskova Battles Back to Advance to 4th Round Against Brady
text: As Zhang Shuai stepped to the baseline, needing one good serve to knock off Karolina Pliskova, the world’s No. 1 player, she did so with experience.

headline: Astros Make Return to Houston, Looking to Help in Hurricane’s Wake
text: HOUSTON — Ten minutes before the start of a day-night doubleheader at Minute Maid Park on Saturday, Houston Astros Manager A. J. Hinch grabbed a microphone and stood in front of home plate.

headline: Mets’ Michael Conforto Will Have Shoulder Surgery
text: HOUSTON — Michael Conforto, the Mets’ lone All-Star this season, will have shoulder surgery in the coming week, John Ricco, the team’s assistant general manager, said Saturday before the Mets’ doubleheader against the Astros. Conforto dislocated his left shoulder on a swing in an Aug. 24 game.

headline: Cambodia Arrests Opposition Leader, Accusing Him of Treason
text: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — The leader of Cambodia’s main opposition party, Kem Sokha, was arrested early Sunday at his home and accused of treason for participating in what the government said was a Washington-backed plot to undermine the country’s leadership.

headline: Corrections: September 3, 2017
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: North Korean Nuclear Test Draws U.S. Warning of ‘Massive Military Response’
text: WASHINGTON — North Korea’s detonation of a sixth nuclear bomb on Sunday prompted the Trump administration to warn that even the threat to use such a weapon against the United States and its allies “will be met with a massive military response.’’

headline: In Phillies’ Gloomy Season, Rookie Rhys Hoskins Is a Beacon
text: Each day last weekend, Rhys Hoskins of the Philadelphia Phillies reached a home run total faster than any player ever had before. He hit his ninth homer that Friday in his 16th career game. He launched his 10th homer the next day, and his 11th the next. No other major leaguer had ever arrived at those mileposts in so few games.

headline: Don Shewey, Andrew Willett
text: Don Shewey and Andrew Willett are to be married Sept. 3 in Upper Black Eddy, Pa. Michael Cohen, a friend of the couple and a Universal Life minister, is to officiate at Longwood Cabin, a home of friends of the couple.

headline: Jennifer Cole, David Feldstein
text: Jennifer Heather Cole and David Harris Feldstein are to be married Sept. 3 at Temple Judea in Manhasset, N.Y. Rabbi Gerald Sussman is to officiate.

text: Robin Elizabeth Wright, the daughter of Federal Judge Susan Webber Wright Carter of Little Rock, Ark., and the late Robert R. Wright III, was married Sept. 2 to Richard Simon Cleary Jr., a son of Helen Bragg C. Cleary and Richard S. Cleary of Louisville, Ky. The Rev. Leo J. O’Donovan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Cathedral of St. Andrew in Little Rock.

headline: Nancy Gunzenhauser, Benjamin Popper
text: Nancy Leigh Gunzenhauser and Benjamin Adam Popper were married Sept. 2 in New Rochelle, N.Y. Judith Wank, an adjunct leader for the Ethical Culture Society of Westchester, N.Y., officiated at the Glen Island Harbour Club.

headline: Jamie Garfinkel, Jonathan Levy

headline: Richa Bhasin, Sridhar Reddy
text: Richa Bhasin and Dr. Sridhar Padala Reddy are to be married Sept. 3 at the Gramercy Park Hotel in Manhattan. William Miller, a State Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn, is to officiate. Earlier in the day, Pandit Ashwartha Narayan, a Hindu priest, is to lead a Hindu ceremony at the New York Ganesh Temple in Flushing, Queens.

headline: Jacqueline Carter, Andrew Klaber
text: Jacqueline Allison Carter and Andrew David Klaber are to be married Sept. 3 at Congregation Shearith Israel in New York. Rabbi Aviad Bodner is to officiate, with Rabbi Meir Y. Soloveichik taking part.

headline: Claire Mauksch, Brian Agler
text: Claire J. Schieffelin Mauksch, the daughter of Sally S. Kentch and Larry B. Mauksch of Seattle, is to be married Sept. 3 to Brian Samuel Agler, a son of Nancy I. Agler and Stuart B. Agler of Needham, Mass. Aaron G. Zucker, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister in order to preside at this event, is to officiate at Fremont Foundry, an events space in Seattle.

headline: Juliet Werner, Andrew DeLaney
text: Juliet Wakerman Werner and Andrew Norton DeLaney were married Sept. 2 at the Wainwright House in Rye, N.Y. Rabbi Andy Bachman officiated.

headline: Matthew Mittelman-Freeman, Adam Rosen
text: Matthew Benjamin Mittelman-Freeman and Adam Jay Rosen are to be married Sept. 3 at the Eugene O’Neill Theater Center in Waterford, Conn. William J. Hibsher, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for this event, is to officiate, with Richard Orient, his husband, taking part in the ceremony

headline: Christina Cordeiro, Stuart Mitchell
text: Dr. Christina Nicole Cordeiro and Dr. Stuart Leighton Mitchell are to be married Sept. 3 in Baltimore. The Rev. Andrew Foster Connors is to officiate at Brown Memorial Park Avenue Presbyterian Church, where he is the senior pastor, with Fritz Bauerschmidt, a Roman Catholic deacon, taking part.

headline: Glennda Testone, Jama Shelton
text: Glennda Lyn Testone and Jama Renee Shelton were married Sept. 2 at the Conventional Hall on the boardwalk in Asbury Park, N.J. Rick Weber, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated, with his husband, Peter Schwartz, also a Universal Life minister, taking part in the ceremony.

headline: Mara Sloan, Benjamin Boroughs
text: Mara Daile Sloan and Benjamin Bryan Boroughs were married Sept. 2. The Rev. Danny R. Reed performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Church in Charleston, which is in Charleston, S.C.

headline: Gregory Schweizer, Jordan Rice
text: Gregory Michael Schweizer and Jordan Andrew Rice were married Sept. 2 in Chicago. Judge Cheryl Ann Krause of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit in Philadelphia, officiated at the Bridgeport Art Center.

headline: When the TV Heroine Is Less Than Perfect
text: We’ve been living in the age of the television antihero for a while now. Tony Soprano, Vic Mackey, Walter White, Frank Underwood, Don Draper — male murderousness and deception wrapped in charisma has been a dominant trope of the TV revolution.

headline: A West Coast Spotlight on Latino Artists Leads the Fall Art Season
text: Size-wise, the biggest deal of the new art season comes right at the start with “Pacific Standard Time: LA/LA,” a roundup of some 70 museum exhibitions in Los Angeles and throughout Southern California devoted to Latin American and Latino art. The chronological arc is wide, from pre-Columbian gold to contemporary performance. So is the ethnic spectrum, with surveys of Afro-Brazilian and Chinese Caribbean art, and work by artists of Japanese descent living in Lima, Peru, and Mexico City.

headline: Retrofitting a Long Island Lighthouse for a Second Act
text: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y. — The Cedar Island Lighthouse, a quaint, cubic structure of notably large granite blocks in Suffolk County’s Cedar Point Park, once appeared a fortress. From atop its stone tower, built in 1868, the lantern light led whaling ships and fishing boats home.

headline: A Toronto Restaurant Both Simple and Iconoclastic
text: You might not know it by appearances, but Brothers Food & Wine in Toronto is run by a couple of young iconoclasts: co-owners Chris White, 30, and Jonathan Nicolaou, 33, who shares chef duties with Keenan McVey, 29. The two met in Toronto culinary circles, then rose up through boundary-pushing London kitchens — Dandelyan for Mr. White; St. John for Mr. Nicolaou.

headline: Why Trump, After North Korea’s Test, Aimed His Sharpest Fire at the South
text: WASHINGTON — While the world agonized over the huge nuclear test in North Korea this weekend, President Trump aimed his most pointed rhetorical fire not at the renegade regime in Pyongyang, but at America’s closest partner in confronting the crisis: South Korea.

headline: Reggaeton, Bachata, Latin Trap? Ozuna Does It All
text: HOBOKEN, N.J. — One evening in late July, the day after the Puerto Rican singer Ozuna’s second straight sold-out concert at Manhattan’s United Palace Theater, he was sitting by the waterfront here, discussing the number of YouTube views his videos receive. “I put on YouTube one single and, in 20 hours, have five million, six million people,” he said. The totals overwhelm him: “In one month, I have 100 million. In one year, one billion. It’s too much.”

headline: Tell Us 5 Things About Your Book: A Sequel to ‘The War of the Worlds’
text: It was 120 years ago that H. G. Wells’s “The War of the Worlds,” about a Martian invasion of Earth, appeared as a magazine serial. (In the United States, the story was rolled out in Cosmopolitan.) Nearly 80 years ago, a radio dramatization of the novel caused “a wave of mass hysteria,” according to The New York Times, among some listeners who didn’t know the terrifying scenario was fiction. Now, Stephen Baxter has written a sequel, “The Massacre of Mankind,” authorized by Wells’s estate. (Baxter is the author of dozens of science-fiction books, and, even more pertinently, a vice president of the H.G. Wells Society.) His book was published in Britain earlier this year, where The Guardian said: “It’s Baxter’s best novel in a long time, and this may be because it reads like a genuine labor of love.” Below, Baxter talks about the evolution of Wells’s original story, his own childhood love of science fiction and more.

headline: Why Can’t We Get Cities Right?
text: The waters are receding in Houston, and so, inevitably, is national interest. But Harvey will leave a huge amount of wreckage behind, some of it invisible. In particular, we don’t yet know just how much poison has been released by flooding of chemical plants, waste dumps, and more. But it’s a good bet that more people will eventually die from the toxins Harvey leaves behind than were killed during the storm itself.

headline: A New Type of Labor Law for a New Type of Worker
text: Labor Day was born in the late 19th century, during a time of raw fear about the path of economic development. Opportunities for decent, middle-class livelihoods seemed to be shrinking, and the “laboring classes” confronted a grim future of what many called wage slavery. Conservatives held most of the seats of power, but reform-minded politicians, activists and policy mavens were thinking big about labor’s rights and wrongs.

headline: Backyard Chickens Carry a Hidden Risk: Salmonella
text: Pet chicks and ducklings seem unlikely culprits in a serious public health problem. But they’re responsible for infecting more than 900 people with salmonella this year — the highest number to date, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
