headline: A Better Beet, Fresh From the Market
text: I know I’m not the only one who grew up on waterlogged canned beets, which definitely predisposes a person to dislike the vegetable. The vacuum-packed, shelf-stable cooked beets are not much better.

headline: Watch the Evolution of Cringe Comedy in 9 Clips
text: Has a more significant television subgenre been born this century than cringe comedy?

headline: Did Leonardo da Vinci Sketch the ‘Nude Mona Lisa’?
text: PARIS — Behind closed doors in the Louvre’s basements, experts have been scrutinizing a drawing for weeks with one question on their minds: Could this semi-naked, mysteriously smiling lady that looks strikingly like the Mona Lisa be a sketch by Leonardo da Vinci?

headline: Review: Why the New ‘Flatliners’ Is Just ‘Meh’
text: Remakes — especially of beloved classics — run the risk of alienating sentimental moviegoers. With “Flatliners,” Columbia Pictures takes a bold, innovative step to address this issue.

headline: Black Lives Matter Can’t Be Sued, Judge Tells Police Officer
text: A judge in Louisiana on Thursday said that Black Lives Matter is a social movement and therefore can’t be sued, dismissing a lawsuit brought by an anonymous police officer.

headline: New Black Boxes Will Be Easier to Track in Plane Crashes at Sea
text: Since the dawn of the jet age, flying has gotten significantly safer. In fact, you are thousands of times more likely to die while driving to the airport than you are flying in a plane.

headline: Rosetta’s Lost Picture From Moments Before It Struck a Comet
text: Nearly a year after it crashed into a comet, the Rosetta spacecraft has given scientists a gift from beyond the grave: the final image of its resting place on Comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko.

headline: In the U.S., 110 Million S.T.D. Infections
text: The incidence of chlamydia, gonorrhea and syphilis is increasing, according to a new report from the Centers for Disease  Control and Prevention. At any given time, there are an estimated 110 million sexually transmitted infections in the United States.

headline: Far-Right Gains Leave Germans Wondering, What Now?
text: BERLIN — As the results of Germany’s election last Sunday flashed on her television screen in the western city of Cologne, Kirsten Schindler, watched with a mixture of confusion and dismay.

headline: 10 Things to Do in NYC Now
text: It’s a big city, with plenty to do, see, hear and watch. Here’s a sampling of cultural highlights this weekend and over the week ahead.

headline: Isabel Marant Wants to Dress You and Your Boyfriend
text: PARIS — Ever since Isabel Marant backed into men’s wear in 2013, designing a few men’s piece for her H&M collaboration, her fans have been asking for more. “I’m inundated by guys asking me, ‘When are you going to do men’s?’” Ms. Marant said before her show in the Palais Royal on Thursday night.

headline: Zuckerberg’s Preposterous Defense of Facebook
text: Responding to President Trump’s tweet this week that “Facebook was always anti-Trump,” Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive of Facebook, defended the company by noting that Mr. Trump’s opponents also criticize it — as having aided Mr. Trump. If everyone is upset with you, Mr. Zuckerberg suggested, you must be doing something right.

headline: Review: The Unstuffy Gala: City Ballet Delivers Youth and Style
text: Five years ago, New York City Ballet’s fall gala became an event for fashion onstage: an annual rendezvous in which new choreography joined new couture. Since 2014, the formula has been four creations, made by four different choreographers, each with a design team from the fashion world.

headline: High Schools Threaten to Punish Students Who Kneel During Anthem
text: The controversy over kneeling in protest of racial injustice moved beyond the world of professional sports this week, when a number of schools told students they were expected to stand during the national anthem.

headline: Jared Kushner’s Entitlement Is New Jersey Born and Bred
text: Jared Kushner, first son-in-law and White House senior adviser, used a personal email account to communicate about government business, it was recently revealed. In his initial application for a security clearance, Mr. Kushner failed to list a single meeting with a foreign government official during the campaign and transition. (Amended forms now reportedly list over a hundred contacts.) He is also, according to official sources, a person of interest in the investigation into the Trump campaign’s dealings with Russia, although when he was recently hauled up to Capitol Hill to testify about a meeting he attended at Trump Tower in June 2016 with a Kremlin-linked lawyer who was promising dirt on Hillary Clinton, he insisted he was entirely blameless.

headline: Mad Virtuosity: The Week’s 8 Best Classical Music Moments on YouTube
text: Our critics and reporters offer a glimpse of what’s moved and delighted them on YouTube. Read the rest of our classical music coverage here.

headline: The Elusive Giant Coconut-Cracking Rat of the Solomon Islands
text: Locals living on the island of Vangunu in the Solomon Islands sing songs about vika, a giant, tree-dwelling rat that can crack open coconuts with its teeth. But scientists had never seen it.

headline: A Collector’s Dream: Creating Your Own Museum as a Legacy
text: Paintings, sculptures, gems, cars, items made perfectly by a single craftsman — if you have the collector’s gene, these are the kinds of things you must own. Add wealth to fuel that desire, and your collection is likely to grow. But then what do you do with it?

headline: Masahiro Tanaka Strikes Out 15 on an Unusual Day for the Yankees
text: The Yankees’ 4-0 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays on Friday performed the function of keeping their faint American League East title hopes alive, at least for another day.

headline: New Trailer: ‘Annihilation’ Puts Natalie Portman in Danger
text: Alex Garland follows up his 2015 directorial debut, “Ex Machina,” with another creepy sci-fi drama featuring Oscar Isaac. Only in “Annihilation,” Mr. Isaac’s character vanishes early on, during a mission into an environmental danger zone, and his wife, played by Natalie Portman, leads an expedition to save him.

headline: The Activist Judge Conservatives Love
text: For some time now conservative Republicans have been screaming about activist judges who put their own political opinions above the law. And they’ve been right to complain. But now, thanks to socially conservative voters in Alabama, we learn that they didn’t really mean it. What bothered them weren’t activist judges in general — but liberal activist judges in particular. Conservative activism by a judge who gets his marching orders from the Bible is apparently fine.

headline: In Atlanta With Guo Pei, Who Spins Stories in Couture
text: When the designer Guo Pei turned 100 days old, her family dressed her in a special outfit made from one of her grandmother’s old silk qipaos in accordance with Chinese tradition. Guo was born during the Cultural Revolution, when citizens were forced to give up all traces of finery and individuality. Girls didn’t wear dresses, clothing was devoid of color and silk was something that Guo rarely saw in her younger years. Her baby outfit was the first beautiful garment that she remembers.

headline: Study Finds More Diversity Among First-Time TV Directors
text: The pool of first-time television directors has grown more diverse, according to a new industry report, but not everyone is convinced of the findings.

headline: Health Secretary Tom Price Resigns After Drawing Ire for Chartered Flights
text: WASHINGTON — Tom Price, the health and human services secretary, resigned under pressure on Friday after racking up at least $400,000 in travel bills for chartered flights and undermining President Trump’s promise to drain the swamp of a corrupt and entitled capital.

headline: I Want My 2.3 Bonus Years

headline: National Anthem Protests, From ‘Jazzing the Banner’ to Taking a Knee
text: The Popcast is hosted by Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic for The New York Times. It covers the latest in pop music criticism, trends and news.

headline: Veterans Agency Seeks to Scrap Ethics Law on For-Profit Colleges
text: The Department of Veterans Affairs is pushing to suspend a 50-year-old ethics law that prevents employees from receiving money or owning a stake in for-profit colleges that pocket hundreds of millions of dollars in tuition paid through the G.I. Bill of Rights.

headline: New Trailer: Gary Oldman Takes on Churchill in ‘Darkest Hour’
text: When it comes to playing Winston Churchill, actors will never, never, never give up. John Lithgow recently won an Emmy as the British bulldog in Netflix’s “The Crown,” and Brian Cox embodied the title role in this year’s biopic “Churchill.” Now Gary Oldman throws his homburg into the ring with “Darkest Hour,” and it’s already earning him best actor Oscar talk.

headline: Don’t Let Puerto Rico Fall Into an Economic Abyss
text: Almost nothing on the planet, short of nuclear weaponry, destroys economic value as rapidly as a mega-hurricane. In Puerto Rico, decades of economic progress were undone in 12 hours by Hurricane Maria.

headline: The Latest Populist Craze in Britain: An Unabashed Elitist
text: LONDON — On a recent afternoon, when the very tall, very thin British lawmaker Jacob Rees-Mogg rose from the bench where he had been reclining, his fellow members of Parliament perked up, confident that what followed would be amusing.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What We’re reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

headline: Azerbaijan Detains Dozens of Gay and Transgender People
text: MOSCOW — More than 50 gay and transgender people in Azerbaijan’s capital, Baku, were detained and abused in a series of raids over the past week, lawyers and rights activists said.

headline: The Perils of Peanut Butter
text: Q. In trying to recycle responsibly, is it worth the hot water needed to clean a jar of peanut butter, or should it not be recycled?

headline: In Puerto Rico, Loved Ones Send Video Messages: ‘We Are Alive’
text: In Utuado, one of the hardest hit towns in Puerto Rico, locals sent video messages to relatives abroad. The community has been without phone or internet connections since Hurricane Maria hit the island.

headline: Tom Price Resigns Under Pressure
text: Tom Price, the health and human services secretary, resigned on Friday. Mr. Price drew criticism for his use of expensive chartered flights, which undermined President Trump’s promise to “drain the swamp” of an entitled capital.

headline: Lady Lucan, Last Witness to a Murder Most Lurid, Dies at 80
text: In November 1974, John Bingham, the seventh Earl of Lucan, a dashing but dissolute gambler, supposedly mistook his children’s nanny for his estranged wife in the dimly lit basement of their London home and bludgeoned her to death. Then he vanished, never to be seen again.

headline: ‘Another Fantastic Week’: Tom Price’s Celebratory Travelogues
text: WASHINGTON — As he traversed the world on taxpayer-funded flights, Tom Price made it a habit to write home, repeatedly sending celebratory letters back to staff members at the Department of Health and Human Services detailing his time on the road, and complimenting agency employees who “ensure the good stewardship of taxpayer dollars.”

headline: Kabul Reels After Attack on Another Shiite Mosque
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Militants disguised as shepherds who were tending a flock of sheep attacked a Shiite mosque in Kabul on Friday as worshipers were leaving, killing five people and wounding at least 20 others, officials said.

headline: Open Thread: This Week in Style News
text: Each week, the Open Thread newsletter will offer a look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. The latest newsletter appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Read the Resignation Letter Tom Price Sent to President Trump

headline: Jeff Flake, in Feud with Trump, Now Faces Challenge from the Left
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Jeff Flake, the Arizona Republican whose public feud with President Trump had already fueled a primary challenge from the right, now has reason to worry about his left flank: Representative Kyrsten Sinema, a centrist Democrat with a powerful biography, announced she will seek Mr. Flake’s Senate seat in 2018.

headline: In Ad, Malliotakis Takes Swing at de Blasio Over Subway Woes
text: The Republican candidate for mayor in New York, Nicole Malliotakis, an assemblywoman from Staten Island, is struggling to get the attention of voters in a heavily Democratic city, with a little more than five weeks before the Nov. 7 election. Ms. Malliotakis just received a payment of $1.5 million in public matching funds from the Campaign Finance Board, giving her campaign a needed boost and making a large advertising purchase possible.

headline: Herbert Kalmbach, Who Figured in Watergate Payoffs, Dies at 95
text: Herbert W. Kalmbach, Richard M. Nixon’s personal lawyer and a conduit for hush money from the 1972 presidential campaign to the Watergate burglars, died on Sept. 15 in Newport Beach, Calif. He was 95.

headline: Digital Currencies Are Growing on Faltering Foundations
text: One of the chief strengths of digital currencies is becoming their weakness.

headline: Where Students Were Stabbed, a School on a Downward Slide
text: Four years ago, on annual school surveys, 94 percent of teachers at the Urban Assembly School for Wildlife Conservation in the Bronx said they would recommend the school to parents, and 80 percent of students said they felt safe in the halls.

headline: Reggie Lavong, Smooth-Voiced D.J., Dies at 84
text: Reggie Lavong, a velvet-voiced radio personality who played rhythm and blues and more in the 1960s on WWRL-AM in New York, died on Sept. 19 in Philadelphia. He was 84.

text: WASHINGTON — A group of federal regulators voted Friday to no longer classify the American International Group as “too big to fail,” freeing the giant insurer from years of tough government oversight.

headline: Haki Madhubuti, the Book Publisher on the South Side
text: CHICAGO — In 1956, when Haki R. Madhubuti was 14 years old and living in Detroit, his mother gave him a firm order: Go down to the public library and check out “Black Boy” by Richard Wright, the seminal memoir on growing up African-American in the segregated South.

headline: Hemingway’s First Short Story Found in Key West
text: When Hurricane Irma smashed into Key West, Fla., author Shel Silverstein’s historic home was nearly leveled. But it was another home in his neighborhood that had Brewster Chamberlin, a writer and historian, worried.

headline: With Widespread Power Failures, Puerto Rico Is Cash Only
text: FAJARDO, P.R. — Juan Jimenez squinted into the dark lobby of his bank early Friday, thinking about the paycheck sitting in his account, just behind the locked doors. If only he could get to it.

headline: CUNY Lecturer Charged With Running Fake Health Certificate Program
text: A biology lecturer at the City University of New York was arrested Friday on fraud and corruption charges, federal and state investigators said, for teaching unauthorized health care classes and selling students fake certificates of completion.

headline: Cubans Alarmed at U.S. Embassy Withdrawals and Travel Warning
text: It was grim, unsettling news: the United States warned Americans on Friday not to travel to Cuba and ordered the withdrawal of more than half its diplomats in Havana.

headline: Texas Man Convicted of Helping Attack U.S. Army Base in Afghanistan
text: In January 2009, two trucks packed with explosives careened toward the front gate of a remote United States Army base in the Khost Province of Afghanistan. The first truck exploded near the gate, injuring a pregnant Afghan woman and several others. But the terrorist plot to kill American soldiers was foiled when the second truck crashed into the blast crater left by the initial explosion.

headline: ‘Botched Plastic Surgery’ Leads to Manslaughter Charge
text: A Queens woman who the authorities say set up appointments for an unlicensed plastic surgery clinic in Manhattan was charged with manslaughter on Friday in the death of a woman who received silicone injections in her buttocks.

headline: At Presidents Cup, the International Team’s Best Pair Falters
text: JERSEY CITY — Louis Oosthuizen had sung the song, and now Nick Price was asking him to live the lyrics.

headline: San Juan Mayor Rebukes Trump Administration for Rosy Comments on Relief Effort
text: SAN JUAN, P.R. — In the storm-battered neighborhood of Barriada Figueroa on Friday, neighbors greeted visitors with a now-familiar question, one that was inevitably followed by a disappointing answer: “Are you FEMA?”

headline: New Virtual Currencies Hit Barriers in U.S. and 2 Other Nations
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Regulators in the United States, South Korea and Switzerland all took independent steps on Friday to crack down on so-called initial coin offerings, a hot but risky new method of raising money for start-ups.

headline: For Trump, a Different Kind of ‘Locker Room Talk’
text: I grew up in a nearly all-white suburb outside of Philadelphia, and no more than 10 percent of my classmates in school were African-American. They lived in a separate, all-black neighborhood of row homes called Bloomsdale. At our high school basketball games, the black students sat together in one corner of the gym. When the national anthem was played, most stayed seated on the wooden bleachers.

headline: As Mets Stagger to Finish Line, Collins Gets Splattered
text: PHILADELPHIA — In what is likely to be his final weekend as the manager of the Mets, Terry Collins had to deal on Friday with the agitation that often accompanies a disappointing season and, in this instance, made him the target.

headline: Suspect in Tennessee Church Shooting Cited Revenge for Charleston Massacre
text: The 25-year-old black man accused of a deadly shooting at a church near Nashville had a note in his car that made reference to revenge for the church massacre carried out by a white supremacist in Charleston, S.C., according to a report by The Associated Press.

headline: Amid Feud With Mayor, Texas Governor Gives $50 Million to Houston
text: HOUSTON — The Democratic mayor of Texas’ largest city and the Republican governor have been publicly clashing over Hurricane Harvey for more than a month, at times turning one of the worst natural disasters to strike the state into a politically tinged feud.

headline: The ‘Hustler’ vs. the Feminist Champion: Inside the ‘Battle of the Sexes’
text: Forty-four years ago this month, Billie Jean King and Bobby Riggs faced off in what may be the most famous tennis match ever televised.

headline: What Not to Learn From Vietnam
text: As the dust settles on the 18-hour documentary “The Vietnam War,” it seems unlikely that the longstanding debates engendered by the conflict will abate much in the film’s aftermath. As is so often the case, most reviews, some written even before the first episode of Ken Burns and Lynn Novick’s epic aired, reveal more about the reviewer than the film itself. When it comes to the war in Vietnam, there are plenty of hobbyhorses to mount.

headline: America’s Cup Will Return to Monohulls in 2021
text: Trust has hardly been the byword for the America’s Cup. For far more than a century, sailing teams have been trying to conceal their cards and design breakthroughs and secure the sport’s most prestigious prize.

headline: Stamped Out

headline: Can Parents Leave a Co-op to a Grown Child? It Depends
text: Q. My husband and I recently updated our will. We want to leave our apartment to our adult daughter. She grew up in the apartment, but now lives on her own. Our lawyer told us to check with the co-op board. To our surprise, it refused our request. What’s the point of having a will if I can’t leave our apartment to our child?

headline: Love Urban Architecture? There Are Maps for That
text: The most visibly arresting buildings are, paradoxically, sometimes the most overlooked in the modern cityscape.

headline: The World According to Dan Brown
text: RYE BEACH, N.H. — Anyone who has read Dan Brown’s work — and with 200 million copies of his books in print, you know who you are — is familiar with his signature technique of inserting little chunks of expository information into the narrative. Among the topics addressed in his latest thriller, “Origin”: the wide-ranging talents of Winston Churchill, the elusive appeal of abstract art, the exciting peculiarities of Gaudi’s Sagrada Familia cathedral and the latest insane developments in the world of artificial intelligence.

headline: 'A Monumental Moment for Women’
text: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment. Some comments were edited for length and clarity.

headline: What’s Up in Coal Country: Alternative-Energy Jobs
text: From the mountain hollows of Appalachia to the vast open plains of Wyoming, the coal industry long offered the promise of a six-figure income without a four-year college degree, transforming sleepy farm towns into thriving commercial centers.

headline: ‘Faux’ Male Feminists Draw Ire in Hollywood

headline: Production of a Lifetime: Whitney Houston and Clive Davis
text: Downstairs at the Beverly Hilton hotel on Feb. 11, 2012, black cars delivered celebrities, among them Serena Williams, Britney Spears and Gayle King, to Clive Davis’s annual Grammys party. Upstairs in Room 434, the coroner’s office tended to the body of his biggest star, Whitney Houston, who had been found dead in the bathtub earlier that day. Police investigators removed empty bottles of liquor while the wails of her daughter, Bobbi Kristina Brown, could be heard down the hall.

headline: A Landscape at Peace With Man and Nature
text: The true test of a garden is how it looks in the rain. Any landscape is lovely garnished with blue skies and butterflies. But in a summer storm?

headline: Designing a Home Without Disrupting the Land’s Healing Energy
text: Agnes Bourne, an interior designer based in Jackson, Wyo., always loved to visit her sister’s rustic dwelling near Spokane, Wash. The 1890s log house was on an astonishing site: next to a lake full of trout, deep within a thousand acres of unlogged forests of Douglas firs and Ponderosa pines. It was filled with open skies, eagles, ospreys, wildflowers and giant boulders, some marked with Native American petroglyphs.

headline: In Russia, Refusing to Disappear in a Crowd
text: “I feel really connected to Moscow, but I also still feel a little bit like a tourist,” Sasha Arutyunova said. Ms. Arutyunova, who lives in Brooklyn, was born in Moscow in 1988, a few years before the Soviet Union collapsed and during an era when Levi’s were still a coveted item in the country. She moved to Florida with her mother when she was 6 years old.

headline: After the Vote, Does the Kurdish Dream of Independence Have a Chance?
text: ERBIL, Iraq — After a century of yearning, the Kurds of Iraq have managed, at last, to pull off a vote for independence, but not without antagonizing nearly everyone in perhaps the world’s most volatile region.

headline: ‘Little Lobbyists’ Help Save the Health Care Law, for Now

But since March, she has made the two-hour drive here from her home in Hanover, Pa., 15 times so her sons, Jackson and Henry, could lobby against efforts to dismantle the Affordable Care Act.

headline: How Two Sentences in Tax Plan May Help Unleash $1 Billion in Lobbying

headline: Shifts Get Real: Understanding the GOP’s Policy Quagmire

Initial assessments of the plan are brutal, and administration attempts to spin things in a positive direction will suffer from loss of credibility on multiple fronts, from obvious lies about the plan itself, to spreading corruption scandals, to the spectacle of the tweeter-in-chief golfing while Puerto Rico drowns.

headline: The Wrong Pill Can Play With Your Mind
text: WHEN I was 16, I was admitted to U.C.L.A.’s neuropsychiatric institute. I’d been suffering from increasing paranoia (I thought war was imminent; I thought I would be called into battle) and lack of sleep (I paced our staircase into the early hours of morning). Most profoundly, I thought my parents were actually secret agents, wearing masks, sent to monitor my behavior.

headline: Speaking Ill of Hugh Hefner
text: Hugh Hefner, gone to his reward at the age of 91, was a pornographer and chauvinist who got rich on masturbation, consumerism and the exploitation of women, aged into a leering grotesque in a captain’s hat, and died a pack rat in a decaying manse where porn blared during his pathetic orgies.

headline: Dear Amazon: Please Build Here
text: Amazon is often promoting the idea of improving the world. Therefore its second headquarters should do that. Knowing that it is a game changer, Amazon should go to a Rust Belt city and forever alter the economy of the region. Take a good look at Pittsburgh or Cleveland. Both have had a renaissance and offer lovely downtowns, beautiful architecture, great waterfronts, beautiful parks, treelined streets, excellent cultural amenities, great public transportation and pro sports teams. Even better, they have great colleges and medical facilities.

headline: Want to Know What Divides This Country? Come to Alabama
text: “Just wow,” Peggy and Mark Kennedy said to each other last week in Montgomery, Ala. On the TV, Roy Moore had just pulled a little pistol from a pocket of his cowboy costume to show his love for the Second Amendment. The next night he won the Republican nomination in the race to be their next senator.

headline: The Latin Mass, Thriving in Southeastern Nigeria
text: UMUAKA, Nigeria — In August, under a bright blue sky and in front of 2,500 worshipers, Bishop Gregory Ochiagha performed the first traditional Latin ordination in Nigeria since the vernacular liturgy was introduced after Vatican II. Near the end of the Mass, the 86-year-old bishop nearly fainted. “I am so happy, I am so happy,” he whispered as he was led to a chair.

headline: Erick Erickson: How to Find Common Ground
text: A year ago my life went to hell. After I declared myself unable to support the election of Donald Trump because of my faith and conservative convictions, three protesters showed up on my front porch. They did not threaten physical harm. But they did express feelings of betrayal and declared their intention to ruin my career as a conservative talk radio host and writer. I needed to carefully reconsider, or else.

headline: Thousands Rally in Dublin Against Ireland’s Abortion Ban
text: Thousands of people marched in Dublin on Saturday to demand an end to the country’s constitutional ban on abortion, one of the strictest such laws in the Western world.

headline: Lin-Manuel Miranda Says Trump Is ‘Going Straight to Hell’

headline: ‘The Social Contract Is Broken’: Inequality Becomes Deadly in Mexico
text: MONTERREY, Mexico — Viewed from above, greater Monterrey, with its corporate headquarters and golf resorts, appears as one city stretching between the mountains that surround it.

headline: China Fears India May Be Edging It Out in Culture Battle
text: BEIJING — One of the most popular movies in China over the summer ran 161 minutes, so long that it was sometimes shown with an intermission. Unlike Hollywood blockbusters, there were no special effects, speeding cars or epic battle scenes. Nor was the film a Chinese production with a Chinese cast.

headline: Statue’s Stolen Foot Reflects Divisions Over Symbols of Conquest
text: ALCALDE, N.M. — The mystery figure appeared at twilight at a rendezvous point in a clearing of piñon trees. He opened his rucksack and revealed plunder hidden for 20 years: the bronze right foot, including spur and stirrup, severed from a statue of Don Juan de Oñate, the despotic conquistador of New Mexico.

headline: Engine Explodes on an Air France Plane, Forcing an Emergency Landing
text: An Air France flight bound for Los Angeles from Paris made an emergency landing in Canada on Saturday after one of the jumbo jet’s four engines exploded in midair, passengers said.

headline: Wild Card Game Awaits the Hot Yankees as Their A.L. East Hopes End
text: The Yankees’ pursuit of the American League East title officially ended late Saturday afternoon when the Boston Red Sox completed a 6-3 victory over the Houston Astros for their 93rd win of the season, a mark the Yankees cannot match. Unofficially, the chase ended about an hour earlier, when the Red Sox opened a 5-0 lead, rendering the Yankees’ 2-0 lead over the Toronto Blue Jays essentially meaningless.

headline: When Budget Vacations Are Your Job
text: My tenure as the Frugal Traveler columnist began inauspiciously. My first official frugal assignment, to Las Vegas, went smoothly enough. But during my second, to Hawaii, I blew out two tires driving on a remote, cell-service-free part of the island, had to be towed 140 miles back to the rental car desk, and was slapped with a $1,500 bill. On my third trip, my bus from Chicago to Milwaukee erupted into a ball of flames. “Someone doesn’t want you to have this job,” a friend suggested.

headline: In the Rangers’ Roster Shuffle, a Teenager Emerges
text: Rangers Coach Alain Vigneault has a favorite phrase when considering roster decisions: “Talent has no age.”

headline: Monty Hall, Co-Creator and Host of ‘Let’s Make a Deal,’ Dies at 96
text: Monty Hall, the genial host and co-creator of “Let’s Make a Deal,” the game show on which contestants in outlandish costumes shriek and leap at the chance to see if they will win the big prize or the booby prize behind door No. 3, died at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif., on Saturday. He was 96.

headline: For Manchester City, Slim Victory at Chelsea Speaks to a Wider Goal
text: LONDON — A few days before Manchester City met Chelsea for the first time last season — a game that, in hindsight, would mark out the latter as Premier League champions-in-waiting and the former as a work in progress — Pep Guardiola came to a realization.

text: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This is a dense puzzle, even for a Sunday, and puzzlers may note with trepidation that four of the six theme answers span or nearly span the entire grid, despite having the briefest of clues.

headline: Inside the Latest Power Struggle at Uber
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The phone calls began late Friday among Uber’s new chief executive, Dara Khosrowshahi, and the ride-hailing company’s executives, as well as board members and a raft of lawyers. They were facing an emergency.

headline: Who Is Carmen Yulín Cruz, the Puerto Rican Mayor Criticized by Trump?
text: SAN JUAN, P.R. — When Carmen Yulín Cruz was a long-shot candidate for mayor here in 2012, she cast herself as a “pitirre,” a small bird known for fearlessly attacking larger ones.

headline: Phil Mickelson, With Family in Tow, Breaks a Presidents Cup Record
text: JERSEY CITY — Spectators ringed the 17th green at Liberty National on Saturday, many of them yelling terms of endearment at Phil Mickelson. “Hoboken loves you, Phil,” one said. But Mickelson played his Presidents Cup foursomes match, a record breaker, primarily for an audience of three.
